item.title: Word of the Day: progeny
item.description: This word has appeared in 43 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Con un mazo dorado y una amenaza a Irán, Trump lanza su Junta de Paz
item.description: Hubo pocos objetivos claros en el primer encuentro de la junta, pero fue como la Asamblea General de las Naciones Unidas, si todo en las Naciones Unidas girara en torno a Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Trump and Indonesia Sign Trade Deal, Locking in 19% Tariffs
item.description: The countries made official an agreement reached last year, with Indonesia avoiding a higher tariff and committing to cooperate on export controls.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson

media:content.media:description: President Prabowo Subianto of Indonesia with President Trump last year.

item.title: This Is How an Autocrat Goes to War
item.description: All that matters to Trump is whether he thinks attacking Iran is in his interests.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Después de Venezuela, ¿sigue Cuba?
item.description: El gobierno de Trump ha endurecido el bloqueo de Estados Unidos a Cuba al cortar el suministro de petróleo extranjero.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Frances Robles and Michael Crowley

media:content.media:description: A tricycle taxi in Havana. The fuel crisis in Cuba is forcing many workers to abandon cars and turn to other forms of transportation.

item.title: Ukrainian Women Tell Their Stories of Sexual Violence by Russian Soldiers
item.description: Hundreds of Ukrainian women and girls have reported sexual violence by Russian troops during the four-year war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Addario and Sara Cincurova

media:content.media:description: Darya with her mother near Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine, in June. Darya said a drunken Russian soldier had forced his hands into her underwear and shouted “I want a young body!”

item.title: By Day, Cortina D’Ampezzo Is an Olympic Hub. By Night, It’s a Party.
item.description: Cortina d’Ampezzo, a small Alpine town in northern Italy, is hosting much of the Winter Games. It’s also a home away from home for rich partygoers.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz

media:content.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Filippo Borghi mixing a cocktail at the Hôtel de la Poste, a famous nightspot in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy.

item.title: They Spun a Globe on Their First Date, and Kept Their Promise
item.description: An all-day first date — and a year that tested them — led Madeline Richter and Jesse Dimitro to a wedding on Valentine’s Day.
item.dc:creator: Donna Kim

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 20, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Feb. 20, 2026.

item.title: A Flirty Weekend Led to Talk of Marriage Just Two Months Later
item.description: Tara Jae and RaeShanda Lias met ahead of a Black Pride event. The two married on Valentine’s Day, with the actress Niecy Nash-Betts officiating.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: ‘You’re My Wife. You’re My Life.’
item.description: When my husband collapsed in our bedroom, it was the nightmare I had long feared, coming true.
item.dc:creator: Stefanie Gunning

item.title: A Shofar Player Wasn’t High on Her Dating Wish List
item.description: Caroline Goldfarb, a comedy writer and producer, never thought she could fall for a ram’s horn player, but that changed after she met Michael Gropper.
item.dc:creator: Rosalie R. Radomsky

item.title: China’s ‘King of Banned Films’ Wants to Change the Subject
item.description: Acclaimed overseas for defying censors, Lou Ye is more interested in reaching Chinese audiences, as he holds up a cinematic mirror to their lives in modern China.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

media:content.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Chinese director Lou Ye, at his studio in Beijing in November.

item.title: Quote of the Day: They Trade Agony for a Few Inches of Stature
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, February 20, 2026.

item.title: Trump Says He’ll Release Alien and U.F.O. Files
item.description: After former President Obama made viral comments about aliens, President Trump said his administration would begin to release government files related to aliens and extraterrestrial life.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump said that he has directed his administration to begin releasing files related to aliens.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Release Files on Aliens and U.F.O.s
item.description: President Trump had lashed out at former President Barack Obama earlier Thursday for telling a podcaster that aliens were real.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump said that he has directed his administration to begin releasing files related to aliens.

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: Emotional Rescue
item.description: Robby and Langdon have an awkward encounter in an elevator. Dana struggles to keep it together in a difficult case involving sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins

media:content.media:description: Langdon and Robby (Patrick Ball, left, and Noah Wyle) were finally forced to air things out ... somewhat, and under less-than-ideal circumstances.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 20, 2026
item.description: Kate Hawkins opens our solving weekend.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

media:content.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Friday puzzles don’t have to be stressful, but keep something squeezable nearby, just in case.

item.title: How Alysa Liu Won Women’s Figure Skating Gold for U.S. at 2026 Olympics
item.description: With seven clean triple jumps, Alysa Liu skated effortlessly to Olympic gold, becoming the first American woman in 20 years to win a medal.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Cai, Weiyi Cai, Bora Erden, Malika Khurana, Jeré Longman, Raj Saha, Joe Ward and Jeremy White

item.title: Eric Dane, McSteamy on ‘Grey’s Anatomy,’ Dies at 53 After Battling ALS
item.description: His breakout role came in 2006 as the handsome Dr. Mark Sloan, nicknamed McSteamy, the head of plastic surgery at a Seattle hospital. He died 10 months after announcing his A.L.S. diagnosis.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

media:content.media:description: Eric Dane revealed in April 2025 that he had A.L.S.

item.title: Relive the Biggest Olympic Skating Jumps, from Alysia Liu to Mikhail Shaidorov
item.description: These animations show the jumps that, in dramatic fashion, made the difference between gold and silver in the women’s and men’s competitions.
item.dc:creator: Alice Fang, Eden Weingart and Jon Huang

media:content.media:credit: Alice Fang, Jon Huang and Eden Weingart/The New York Times

item.title: New Trump Banner Hung on Justice Dept. Headquarters in D.C.
item.description: Other federal buildings across Washington, D.C., are also adorned with huge banners of President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Department of Justice in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Has a Head-Spinning Day, but Republicans Want Him to Focus
item.description: President Trump’s advisers want him to lock down a message on the economy that will resonate ahead of the midterms. But Mr. Trump is never one to stay on message.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump used much of his speech in Rome, Ga., on Thursday to address tangents: railing against the Supreme Court, making false claims of voter fraud and calling himself a “schmuck” for donating his presidential salary.

item.title: HUD Revives First-Term Trump Proposal to Eject Undocumented Immigrants from Public Housing
item.description: When the Trump administration proposed the rule in 2019, housing officials estimated it would also displace thousands of U.S. citizens and legal residents.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A public housing complex in New York City.

item.title: Bard College Opens Review of Its President’s Ties to Jeffrey Epstein
item.description: The move comes after a trove of documents released by the Justice Department showed Leon Botstein had a relationship that was closer than previously known with the convicted sex offender.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel

media:content.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Bard College campus in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.

item.title: Venezuela Passes Amnesty Bill Denounced by Some as ‘Unjust’
item.description: The bill may bring the release of hundreds of political prisoners. But many critics say the legislation, passed after major pressure from the Trump administration, raises concerns.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Annie Correal, Patricia Sulbarán, Isayen Herrera and Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:description: Families gathered last month for a vigil outside El Rodeo I, a prison east of Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: MAHA Moms Turn Against Trump: ‘Women Feel Like They Were Lied To’
item.description: President Trump’s executive order aimed at spurring production of a pesticide has infuriated leaders of Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s MAHA movement.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Hiroko Tabuchi

media:content.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Supporters of Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. onstage with him at a news conference last year.

item.title: As Trump Weighs Iran Strikes, He Declines to Make Clear Case for Why
item.description: Rarely in modern times has the United States prepared to conduct a major act of war with so little explanation or public debate.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump speaking at the inaugural Board of Peace meeting in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Investigators Blame NASA and Boeing for Starliner Failures
item.description: Technical and oversight problems left two astronauts aboard the International Space Station for months longer than had been expected.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

media:content.media:description: The Boeing Starliner spacecraft that carried the astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams to the International Space Station, seen on July 3, 2024.

item.title: How Did Draco Malfoy Get Mixed Up With Lunar New Year?
item.description: It all comes down to a love of wordplay.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca L. Davis

media:content.media:description: A Lunar New Year display showing a young Tom Felton as Draco Malfoy in Shangqiu, China, this month.

item.title: Three Words That Shape Our Politics
item.description: Is Donald Trump “country” or “cowboy”? The Times Opinion columnist Tressie McMillan Cottom breaks down a cultural trend she sees shaping politics today.
item.dc:creator: Tressie McMillan Cottom

item.title: Trump Calls Himself a ‘Schmuck’ for Donating His Presidential Salary
item.description: President Trump complained that he gets “no credit” for the donations, though his family has done more to monetize the presidency than anyone who has ever occupied the White House.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump spoke at the Coosa Steel Corporation in Rome, Ga., on Thursday.

item.title: Blue Owl Capital Sets Off New Fears About the Private Credit Industry
item.description: The lender’s announcement that investors will no longer be able to ask for a set amount of money back from its funds prompted worries about the private credit industry.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell

media:content.media:description: Blue Owl Capital, the large private lender, has amassed nearly $300 billion in investor money.

item.title: Police Investigate ICE Arrest of a Man Who Suffered Severe Head Injuries
item.description: The police in St. Paul, Minn., are investigating an arrest last month during the immigration crackdown. The man has said he was beaten by agents. ICE asserted that he ran into a wall.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

media:content.media:description: Alberto Castañeda Mondragón told The Associated Press that he was in a friend’s car at a shopping center in St. Paul, Minn., when immigration agents pulled him from the car.

item.title: How The Times Made Judgment Calls on Covering the Arrest
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor was arrested on suspicion of misconduct in public office, then released hours later. Two Times reporters explain how they are covering the unprecedented moment.
item.dc:creator: Megan DiTrolio

media:content.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, formerly known as Prince Andrew, was arrested and released on Thursday.

item.title: Ex-Police Commissioner’s Lawsuit Against New York City Is Dismissed
item.description: Thomas G. Donlon had claimed he was fired for exposing corruption within the Police Department and City Hall. He briefly served as interim commissioner under Mayor Eric Adams in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.category: Eric Adams Federal Corruption Case (24 CR 556)

media:content.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Thomas G. Donlon, center, filed a lawsuit that claimed that Mayor Eric Adams, left, and top police officials had run a criminal enterprise while he was police commissioner.

item.title: Trump’s Board of Peace Promises Billions for Gaza, With Few Details
item.description: At the inaugural meeting of his new organization, President Trump also endorsed a divisive foreign leader and heard an attack on his former prosecutor, Jack Smith.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley

media:content.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Nine Board of Peace member countries have agreed to contribute more than $7 billion to the Gaza rebuilding effort, President Trump announced Thursday.

item.title: With ‘Tremendous’ Deals at Stake, Trump Is Bringing Russia in From the Cold
item.description: Since President Trump took office more than a year ago, the Kremlin has dangled possible investments in front of the famously transactional leader. The message is starting to resonate with investors.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

media:content.media:description: President Trump with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a meeting in Alaska last year.

item.title: British Police Arrest Former Prince Andrew Amid Scrutiny Over Epstein Ties
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, a longtime associate of Jeffrey Epstein, is being investigated on suspicion of misconduct in public office.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Michael D. Shear and Michael Levenson
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom

media:content.media:description: Police officers at an entrance to Wood Farm on the royal family’s Sandringham Estate on Thursday, where Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor was living.

item.title: Former Prince Andrew’s Arrest Casts Shadow Over UK Monarchy
item.description: The arrest of the former prince could shake public confidence in the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom

media:content.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor on King Charles III’s coronation day in 2023.

item.title: The Former Prince Andrew Is Arrested
item.description: Also, Trump hints at the possibility of military action in Iran. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor in a photo from last year.

item.title: Trump Administration Uses ‘Equal Time’ Rule to Reshape Late-Night TV
item.description: The F.C.C. is using the “equal time” provision to take aim at hosts like Stephen Colbert. The impact could reshape how talk shows handle politics.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin and Jim Rutenberg
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

media:content.media:description: Stephen Colbert took “The Late Show” in a more political direction after becoming its host in 2015.

item.title: Southern Plains Braces for More Wildfires While Battling Old Ones
item.description: Unusually warm temperatures, dry air, parched vegetation and strong wind gusts have fueled wildfires, which have broken out across Oklahoma and Texas this week.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

item.title: Doug Moe, 87, N.B.A. Coach as Freewheeling as His Style of Play, Dies
item.description: A former college All-American touched by scandal, he was irreverent and unpredictable as he piloted his fast-paced Nuggets and Spurs.
item.dc:creator: Harvey Araton

media:content.media:description: Doug Moe coaching the Denver Nuggets in 1985. A sports journalist’s dream, he was once fined by the N.B.A. front office for throwing water on a referee.

item.title: Alysa Liu’s comeback ends in gold.
item.description: Liu became the first American to win a medal in women’s figure skating since 2006.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Vincent Alban

item.title: Cees Nooteboom, Voyaging Author of Enigmatic Novels, Dies at 92
item.description: A prolific Dutch writer of fiction, poetry and travel books, he was often mentioned as a potential recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

media:content.media:description: Cees Nooteboom in 2015. The author of dozens of works of fiction, poetry, journalism and travel writing, he was perennially mentioned as a possible recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature.

item.title: Austrian Man Found Guilty in Girlfriend’s Death on Mountain Hike
item.description: Thomas Plamberger was given a suspended prison sentence and fined in a case that tested the limits of personal responsibility in mountaineering.
item.dc:creator: Helena Smolak and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: In ‘Passerby,’ an Artist Documents Women’s Lives One Photo at a Time
item.description: For a decade, Clémence Polès Farhang asked women on city streets if she could take their picture. This week, the photographs had their first exhibition.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Gellman

item.title: Britain Updates: Former Prince Andrew Is Released After Being Arrested Amid Epstein Revelations
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, who is still under investigation, was seen leaving police custody on Thursday evening after being detained on suspicions of misconduct in public office.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
